member.name: T:Atropos.FullCheck
member.summary: A class that exposes evaluation methods for checking user-defined equality and ordering APIs.

remarks.para: The purpose of the class is to provide a simple interface by which to evaluate the full slate of API methods that describe equality and ordering for custom types. These functions are generally expected to be internally consistent, but it can be tedious to manually evaluate each one individually. This is exacerbated by the optionality of most elements of the API and the relative difficulty of discovering their presence for an arbitrary type. The functions exposed by allow unit tests to succinctly express their intents without being concerned as to the actual methods that are physically invoked.

When evaluating equality, tests the most appropriate overload of any binary equality operators, the inherited method, and any strongly typed Equals(T?) methods brought in via . Furthermore, if equality is expected, the method is evaluated as well. Appropriate symmetry is assumed: i.e. if testing that A is equal to B, will also test that B is equal to A.

When evaluating ordering, tests the most appropriate overload of any binary ordering operators and any strongly typed CompareTo(T?) methods brought in via . Note that neither operator== nor operator!= is evaluated for ordering, as equivalence and equality are treated separately. Appropriate symmetry is also assumed: i.e. if testing that A is strictly less than B, will also test that B is strictly greater than A.

is intended as a utility for unit testing but is not tied to any particular unit testing framework or paradigm. To support the client's choice of testing platform, all of the APIs exposed by return an optional denoting the result of the evaluation. If the evaluation succeeds (i.e. the test passes), the optional will be a NONE instance. If, on the other hand, the evaluation fails (i.e. the test fails), the optional will be a SOME instance that contains the failed expression. This allows users to build thin adapters on top of the methods to handle failure appropriately, including a useful error message if so desired.

member.name: M:Atropos.FullCheck.ExpectLessThan``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Determines if the full ordering API exposed by a type indicates that one instance of that type is strictly less than another instance.
member.param: The first of the two arguments.
The second of the two arguments.
member.returns: A SOME instance with the expression that, when evaluated, indicates that is not strictly less than if such an expression exists; otherwise, a NONE instance.

member.name: M:Atropos.FullCheck.TestOrdering``1(``0,``0,System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Evaluates the ordering relation between two instances of a type using the full ordering API of that type.
member.param: The first of the two arguments.
The second of the two arguments.

A negative integer if is expected to be strictly less than , 0 if is expected to be equivalent to , a positive integer if is expected to be strictly greater than , and if is expected to be incomparable to .
member.returns: If the ordering relation between and is not the same as that indicated by , a SOME instance whose value is the expression that exposed the failed ordering. Otherwise, a NONE instance.

member.name: T:Atropos.Moq.CallSequence`1
member.summary: A utility for ensuring that calls made through a occur in a specific order.

remarks.para: A common need when unit testing complex components is to ensure that a series of calls to the system under test occur in a particular order. While the Moq library provides many powerful facilities for mocking objects and evaluating the ensuing behavior, the library is lacking when it comes to evaluating call sequences. fills this gap, interoperating with the hierarchy seamlessly to provide a fluent way to expect a specific order of invocations.

A begins empty, i.e. with no expectations, and can be augmented one expected call at a time. Any expected call that can be set-up via can be added to a . imposes a custom callback that verifies the calls are made in the correct order. For this reason, however, it is not possible to add an additional user-defined callback that is invoked after the order-check passes. This feature is under consideration as a future extension of the library. If a call is made out-of-order, an exception is raised with robust information regarding the expectation of the versus reality.

A necessarily imposes an immutable strict total order. This means that an expected call cannot be reordered or removed once added, and that every expected call must occur either before or after each other expectation. For example, it is not possible to expect that both call A and B occur, in any order, before call C. It is, however, possible to expect repeated calls, either sequentially (e.g. A, A, B) or non-sequentially (e.g. A, B, A). There are limitations to repeat call support, as detailed below.

A is in one of three states at any given time: not yet started, incomplete, or complete. A can be extended in any state, adding an additional expected call to the end; specifically, adding an expected call to an incomplete sequence does not set the expectation of the next call. A is complete when all expected calls have been made; one can verify that a is complete using a dedicated API, which will throw an exception in the adverse case. An empty (i.e. one without any expected calls) is always considered complete.

Calls can be made to the that backs a that are not directly expected by the sequence. The strict total order imposed on the calls by a sequence does not preclude other calls; to verify that no other calls are made, use a combination of the method on the and the method on the underlying .

A single can underlie more than one as long as those sequences contain disjoint sets of expected calls. If an expected call appears in multiple sequences that are backed by the same , at least one of the sequences will fail. The other major limitation of has to do with repeat expectations: to include a repeated expectation in a sequence, the LINQ expression with which the expectation is established must use the same lambda variable names. For example, x => x.Foo() and y => y.Foo(), while representing the same invocation, will cause a containing both to fail on the first invocation. This variable naming is case sensitive, so x => x.Foo() is also different than X => X.Foo().

member.typeparam: The type of object being mocked by the underlying .

member.name: M:Atropos.Moq.CallSequence`1.Add(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Action{`0}})
member.summary: Adds an expected call to the end of the current call sequence. This can be used to extend a sequence that has not yet been started, a sequence that is in progress, or a sequence that has already completed. Call expectations cannot be reordered or removed once added.
member.param: The LINQ denoting the call to be added to the end of the current call sequence.
member.returns: The produced by using to set-up an expectation on that backs the current .
